Numerous small wet loose avalanches from the past few days on E S W aspects.  Wet loose activity expanded to NE aspects yesterday and today mostly BTL with a few tiny ones N/ATL.  A couple of recent long running wet loosies on Cinnamon were borderline D2s.  A wet loose on Schuylkill Ridge triggered a fresh D1.5 slab.  Adding a few previously undocumented old wet slabs from the March Meltdown.

column20: A handful of large wet slabs ran either today or yesterday on easterly aspects N/BTL on weak layers near the ground. ENE seemed to be the sweet spot.  The Gibson Ridge slide ran sometime between 2:30 and 3:25 p.m. today.   Of course there are lots of undocumented wet loose avalanches; difficult to pin down the timing I'm coding just a few of the larger/fresher looking ones.

Besides the avalanche I investigated there were two other large cornice fall avalanches. The cornices gouged out snow on the slope but did not trigger Persistent Slab avalanches. I also observed several small Loose Wet avalanches across the highway in the Big Marvin avalanche path (East Vail area). These may be a few days old.

I triggered a small avalanche on a northeast 40-degree convex roll near treeline. The avalanche was confined to the recent storm snow and moved slower than expected on the supportable crust beneath the new snow. No cracking observed in the new snow prior to the avalanche.

D1 to D2 wet loose activity from the past few days is too numerous to document or date confidently.  I'm coding the larger or fresh ones here.  We observed several run today.  Wet loose slides have occurred on all aspects except due north.  We triggered a few wet loose this afternoon; steep rocky SE slopes were gouging through most of the snowpack.  The only notable slab avalanche we observed was in the West Elk Wilderness - a large slab (appeared to be dry) on an east aspect that looks like it was triggered by a wet loose avalanche recently I'm guessing yesterday.

Skier 1 traveled ski cut across the slope several very small loose released just off their ski tips with top 8-10cm of wet snow breaking on cold snow below. Skier 2 traveled in the same track as skier 1 about halfway across the slope a wet slab 10' wide broke below Skier 2. Skier 2 was not caught. The small pocket moved downhill and triggered a much larger wet slab. This avalanche was 200'-300' wide with a crown depth from 30-70cm.  CBAC notes: After a site investigation on 3/25 changed avalanche type from wet slab to soft slab because the main slab on east to northeast facing terrain was mostly dry. It entrained a significant amount of wet snow as it descended and wrapped to warmer aspects thus the debris was wet.  The initial shallow slab on a southeast aspect was wet.  We estimated the debris was large enough to destroy a car and adjusted the size from D2.5 to D3.

column20: Skied a south facing slope on Gothic. We found great soft conditions around 10:15 at upper elevations. Mid and lower elevations this timeframe was a bit past prime.   We saw another group cut across a steep north east facing slope (very close to the ridge line) to access a south facing slope. While they traversed the caused a small loose/wet avalanche that grew quite large and triggered a slab avalanche. No one caught.

D1 to D2 wet loose activity from the past few days is too numerous to document or date confidently.  I'm coding the larger or fresh ones here.  We observed several run today.  Wet loose slides have occurred on all aspects except due north.  We triggered a few wet loose this afternoon; steep rocky SE slopes were gouging through most of the snowpack.  The only notable slab avalanche we observed was in the West Elk Wilderness - a large slab (appeared to be dry) on an east aspect that looks like it was triggered by a wet loose avalanche recently I'm guessing yesterday.

column20: Numerous WL on all aspects as the sun ran around the compass. Nothing bigger than a D1.5 but most were non-destructive.

Above billy barr's house

column20: West face of Emery peak slid after 1 snowmobiler drove onto the upper bench onto a previously established snowmobile track. . Sled was approx 800ft away from the avalanche crown and was descending the bench when snow started moving. Was able to outrun it without a problem. Sympathetic release occurred on the South West face of Emery approx 300ft from the main slide.

column20: We triggered one avalanche remotely.  Observed a handful of other natural avalanches along Schuylkill Ridge and a few small loose avalanches on steep rocky sunny slopes.
column21: The debris is visible just past the shadow in the basin.  I could not identify the type of avalanche given the poor light.  The size is a best guess but it could easily be a D2.  The freshness of the debris suggests it ran late Saturday or early Sunday.

column20: Small wet loose avalanches were plentiful. Typicaly releasing from rock out crops on steep southerly facing slopes.   Triggered a large avalanche on a ENE facing slope of Mt Axtel. This was an interesting avalanche as it released on multiple different interfaces. It even stepped down to the January drought layer and gouged to the ground in some places. The 3/13 interface was the same story with 1mm to 1.5mm facets on a crust on ENE or the same facets without the crust on more NE-facing sections of the crown. The January drought layer was larger 2 to 3mm facets. Crown heights were all over the place from 20cm to over 2m.
column21: Crown and debris look fresh.

column20: Piles of roller balls and small wet loose avalanches are plentiful across the southern half of the compass after two warm days. Throwing roller balls onto steep E-SE facing slopes produced piles of roller balls amassing and they would occasionally trigger a small wet loose avalanche.  I got two separate collapses above a SE facing slope at 11800ft. One collapse triggered a tinny slab that went on to trigger piles of roller balls. The other collapses broke a cornice which amassed into a small wet loose avalanche.

Small wet loose avalanches were plentiful. Typicaly releasing from rock out crops on steep southerly facing slopes.   Triggered a large avalanche on a ENE facing slope of Mt Axtel. The 3/13 interface was the same story with 1mm to 1.5mm facets on a crust on ENE or the same facets without the crust on more NE-facing sections of the crown. The January drought layer was larger 2 to 3mm facets. Crown heights were all over the place from 20cm to over 2m.
column21: Triggered a large avalanche on a ENE facing slope of Mt Axtel. This was an interesting avalanche as it released on multiple different weak layers. It even stepped down to the January drought layer and gouged to the ground in some places. The 3/13 interface was the same story with 1mm to 1.5mm facets on a crust on ENE or the same facets without the crust on more NE-facing sections of the crown. column20: Jumped on a test slope nearby with propagation.   Ski cut the slope and triggered slide near sapling on margin of wind lip.  Slope was convex 45 degree rollover.  Broke on old/new interface around 2pm. Slab was F this afternoon. Soft debris SS-ASc-R1-D1
Notable windslabs today: SS-ASc-R2-D1-i 8-10"" deep 150' wide SS-ASc-R2-D1-i ran through choke into apron SS-ASc-R2-D1.5 8-10"" deep 150' wide ran to lower apron

Two very small slides human triggered.

Observed a fresh (with the last 2 days) very large (D3) avalanche off the north side of Treasure Mountain a recent large (D2) avalanche off Ragged Peak got a better look at the very large (D3) avalanche off Ragged Mountain (https://avalanche.state.co.us/report/b9815e2e-41aa-4c93-b25d-393d39f642b4) from less than a week ago and many Loose Wet avalanches on south-facing slopes.

We intentionally triggered wind slab avalanches on steep south and southeast convex features. These avalanches were relatively harmless to people and very small relative to path. These avalanches were breaking within the new snow rather than on the old crust (SS-ASc-R1-D1-S). We did not see any natural avalanches.

Observed a few small Wind Slabs from the last few days several small Loose Wet avalanches and got a closer look at the recent Willoughby Ridge avalanche from last week.

While targeting an area to dig we remotely triggered a large D2.5 avalanche. This avalanche failed on small 1mm to 1.5mm facets at the 3/13 interface. The crown broke on a cross-loaded terrain feature and then propagated across much of the avalanche path. The crown height averaged in the 45cm to 55cm range with a max crown height of around 70cm. The avalanche ran 1800ft and pushed into the flat valley below.

column20: A skier triggered a large (D2) to very large (D3) avalanche on the west side of Mount Justice above North Anthracite Creek on March 20. The avalanche broke just below the skier and they cut the skier's left to avoid being caught. It started as a relatively small avalanche in the new snow and ran a couple hundred feet before stepping down to deeper buried weak layers. The avalanche was large enough to break small trees and stopped just a couple hundred feet shy of the creek.
column21: Failed on the March 3 interface (notice the dust on the bed surface) then stepped down to deeper weak layers likely the January drought weak layer.

column20: Ski cut on the top of the rightmost chute resulted in a small wind slab avalanche. Crown was 20cm at its largest entrained a lot of snow and ran almost to the lake. When skiing both this chute and the looker left it was very easy to get dry loose to move (lots of sluff).  Noted one natural slide in the upper basin above the avalanche that Ian reported. It appeared to have started at the top of the bowl. I have one very bad photo of this I'll attach.
NE shoulder of Brown Mountain above Ironton around 11300’.

column20: Day Started by Skiing NNE aspect near and below tree line ridge of Nirvana Trees and into Nevada gully. Observed no signs of instability. Upon getting back up around the world there were other tracks in Nirvana trees and a different party of skiers had skied the lowest angle but center gut of Nevada bowl (2 skiers with a dog). Second run was Swamp (skiers right swamp creature) with soft snow on a solar crust. Observed no signs of instability and great skiing. Decided to skin up for a 3rd run and ski back to Ophir via Swamp Angel (NNW). Upon seeing tracks in Nevada Bowl and others there were comments about the Persistent slab and how dangerous it was. There is definitely a sleeping dragon as CAIC reporter mentioned and base structure was generally poor but the lack of observations resulted in a false sense of confidence in the ""dormancy"" of this persistent slab below tree line.  Incident: Skier 1 went first and took an aggressive ski cut towards the skiers left (more north facing ridge) and skied the ridge down crossing another gully and to the ""safety"" pictured. No signs of instability on this run. Skier 2 skied just below skier 1's tracks and upon reaching the ridge caused a D2 avalanche below their skies (pictured) and Skier 1 yelled avalanche from the ridge ""safety"" down below. Skier 2 did not get caught or carried the avalanche debris flowed down the gully (traveling ~800 feet of distance) not near Skier 1 sympathetically releasing another small avalanche on the W facing slope (pictured) and Skier 1 was able to get a photo of the avalanche likely stepping a bit closer to the gully at this point. The first avalanche crown was estimated to be 80cm at its highest point and the W facing crown was estimated to be the new storm snow since Thursday?  Skier 2 then proceeded skiing down the ridge and reached Skier 1 and stopped skiers left of Skier 1. Skier 3 then skied down the ridge staying very close to the tracks of skiers 1 and 2 and crossed the other gully (the south arm of the Y of Swamp Angel). Upon reaching this sub-ridge Skiers 1 and 2 were on Skier 3 turned and caused another avalanche on the ridge skiers 1 and 2 had skied. Skier 3 was knocked off their feet and in the trees but was not carried. They observed a crown of roughly 2 feet and a bed surface of facets. At this time Skiers 1 and 2 heard and felt a loud collapse yelled and the snowpack fractured under their feet into numerous blocks moving downhill. Skier 2 was able to side step and grab a tree but Skier 1 tried to grab a small tree below them and was knocked off their feet and drug down into the gully with the moving snow. At this point Skier 1 deployed their air bag and was carried 260 vertical feet. periodically coming above and below the snow while rapidly moving down the gully. Skier 1 struck a small tree and lost their pole but ended up relatively unscathed (just some bruises) and on top of the debris (they think the airbag was an important part of this).  Upon coming out of the snow Skier 1 yelled uphill and started to initiate a search but quickly heard that skiers 2 and 3 had not been carried. During this incident skier 3 skied down the faceted bed surface and reached Skier 2 and they started to initiate a search but quickly heard from skier 1` yelling up at them and then radioing they were okay. All skiers proceeded to take the safest route down.  Main Takeaways: This incident clearly reflects the challenging and dangerous aspects of a Persistent Slab problem. The group made a poor decision skiing that steep of terrain and was incorrectly given confidence by a lack of any signs of instability. Furthermore the ""safety"" chosen reflected a concern of surface instability and not a deeper and widespread persistent slab problem and they should have taken this into consideration after seeing the first avalanche because the safe zone was indeed not safe. Stay safe out there folks.

column20: Large natural stepping down to ground and sympathetically triggering more avalanches on lower benches.
column21: Large natural stepping down to ground and sympathetically triggering more avalanches on lower benches.

No instabilities observed via standard Coneys approach and uptrack. Skied 1st lap in main bowl with no signs of instability. Traveled to the high point on the ridge to consider second lap options. Obvious wind lip north of the high point along the ridge. Observed 2 ski tracks from earlier in the day that started from the high point on the ridge but did not trigger anything. Continued traveling north from the high point for approximately 25 feet when the slide was triggered. Crown approximately 2 ft deep and 200 ft wide slid on old bed surface.

Our party was the recipient of a free lesson today after triggering an avalanche on the very terrain feature we identified as the feature of concern on our final run of the day. The feature is an open convex role at 11400 NW aspect. The opening rolls at the very top and we determined we would not ski it from the top but ski the open trees on the skier's left and work into the opening lower down avoiding the roll at the top. 3 out of 4 party members skied to the skier's left edge of the opening below the roll to stop for eyes and skier 4 stopped slightly uphill prior to skiing into the opening in the planar part of the slope which measured right at 35 degrees. On his 3rd turn there was a large collapse and the avalanche broke ~50' above him. By the time it gathered much velocity he was down and out of the path.

A skier triggered an avalanche on their second turn. They were able to ski off of the moving slab of snow.

The slope that avalanched slid multiple times earlier this season and was significantly more shallow than adjacent slopes. The avalanche erased the tracks of two backcountry tourers that had crossed the same slope the day prior after one of them was caught in a small avalanche just below the ridgeline. The two skiers from the previous day also  remotely triggered an avalanche just below the accident site.

column20: A skier triggered and skied out of an avalanche on a northeast-facing slope near treeline north of Chair Mountain on Saturday March 8. The skier kept his speed up and skied off the avalanche without being knocked over or dragged down the slope.

column20: Two large soft slab avalanches ran in Wang Chung and 4th Bowl during the storm.  These were slabs of new and drifted snow that likely failed on March 3 interface a couple feet deep.  Yesterday a skier triggered a similar avalanche in the Pencil while skiing across the top of the start zone and today we triggered one in Quill by stomping and pushing at a drifted feature from the ridgeline (See video).  These avalanches are a hybrid of problems: wind-drifted storm snow over a faceted weak layer.

column20: This avalanche was triggered by a solo powsurfer a rider on a snowboard with no bindings on Colorado Mines Peak (Mines Peak) east of Berthoud Pass in an area locally known as High Trail Cliffs. High Trail Cliffs is a series of four steep rocky northwest-facing avalanche paths that are easily accessed from the parking area at the top of the pass. It was a hard slab avalanche. The avalanche was medium-sized relative to the path and destructive enough to injure bury or kill a person. It released on a weak layer of buried faceted crystals and stepped down to the ground entraining the entire season’s snowpack (HS-ARu-R3-D2-G). The crown face averaged about 2 feet deep and was about 550 feet wide across all four of the avalanche paths in the High Trail Cliffs. The avalanche ran about 525 vertical feet through sparse trees and rocky terrain. The avalanche broke small trees and the debris and broken limbs piled up on a bench below the slope. Debris was over 7 feet deep in places. Portions of the debris reached the historic maximum trimline of the avalanche path.

We were attempting to circumnavigate a more obviously threatening gully beneath us so we doubled back and over it travelling beneath the eventual slide path. We decided to cross it one at a time. I hadn't taken two steps before the slope slid—it broke ahead of and above me. Fortunately I was on the margins of the slide. Debris moved around my legs but did not dislodge me from the slope and I was able to backtrack out of it safely.

column20: This was a soft slab avalanche unintentionally triggered by a backcountry skier. The avalanche was medium-sized relative to the path and destructive enough to injure bury or kill a person. The avalanche broke on a facet-crust combination (SS-ASu-R3D2.5-O). The crown face of the avalanche was generally 2 to 3 feet deep and up to 5 feet at the deepest point. The avalanche propagated around a ridge and ran on slopes facing north through east. The avalanche was up to 1300 feet wide and ran 1400 vertical feet. Debris split around several stands of dense trees and other terrain features resulting in several paths of flow. The avalanche ran into a narrow gully at the bottom of the path and then down the gully following the Mineral Creek drainage. Debris spanned over 2000 feet along the gully split into multiple piles and was more than 20 feet deep in places. A smaller avalanche released sympathetically about 450 feet to the west on a similar aspect near treeline (SS-ASy-R3-D2-O).

column20: Around twenty arge to very large natural avalanches ran in the past few days (since we had good visibility on Sunday 2/16) from wind drifting.  Most of these appeared to be persistent slabs breaking on the January dryspell layer or deeper.  A few looked to be shallower wind slabs.  There's also lingering evidence of widespread natural activity during the big storm; I'm only documenting a handful of the more obvious or larger avalanches here.

column20: Upper Dragon's tail 10600ft SE
Several large avalanches around Peak 1. With the poor visibility and crowns also obscured by additional snow it was hard to determine the extent of activity.

I saw two avalanches from CR129 in an area locally known as The Fingers. Both were on east aspects around 8500’. One ran naturally and failed within a layer of the storm snow likely sometime yesterday. The other avalanche occurred on a wind loaded slope and also failed within a layer of the storm snow but I could not discern what triggered it and it occurred sometime prior to yesterday during this recent storm cycle.

The northeast side of Mud Peak released naturally likely on Monday. This was a very large avalanche that broke around 800 feet wide. It snapped large timber and the debris ran over 1500 vertical feet.  This avalanche took out areas locally known as the Money Shot and the Benjamins and the debris ran to the hill on a terrain feature locally known as Middle Earth.  This avalanche would have been unsurvivable if someone was caught in it.
Several large avalanches around Peak 1. With the poor visibility and crowns also obscured by additional snow it was hard to determine the extent of activity.
A very large avalanche occurred on Garrett Peak sometime between February 16 and February 17 2025.

Although many avalanches from the Valentine's Day cycle likely filled in beyond recognition widespread avalanche activity remains visible in the upper North Anthracite Creek drainage. Many older crowns are likely from the tail end of the Valentine's Day cycle and many avalanches from the past few days are also present.

This avalanche occurred on the east face of Shrine Mountain west of Vail Pass in an area locally known as Shrine Bowl. It was a soft slab avalanche unintentionally triggered by a snowmobiler. The avalanche was medium-sized relative to the path and large enough to bury injure or kill a person. The avalanche broke on faceted crystals near the ground. It was approximately 2 to 4 feet deep and 550 feet wide. It ran around 350 vertical feet (SS-AMu-R3-D2-G).

The avalanche occurred on a South slope at 6700 ft.  The slope was open with clusters of trees.  Many of the details are unknown because both skiers were buried and killed.  They were found with their skins on and it is suspected that they triggered the avalanche while skinning midway up the path.  The avalanche was a size 2 Storm Slab which propagated surprisingly far given the nature of the weak layer (compression tests throughout the range near the slide and along the crown yielded mostly resistant planar results) which was a layer of mostly intact stellar dendrites buried beneath 40-55 cm. of more recent and harder storm snow.  The bed surface was a melt-freeze crust which was very isolated throughout the range.  Details of how the avalanche was triggered remain unknown but clusters of trees throughout the slope and in the runout exacerbated the consequences of the avalanche.

Remotely triggered an avalanche from at least 200 feet away that broke in dense trees. The crown was all new snow from the past few days and the avalanche failed on the old snow surface of well-developed near-surface facets.

column20: I remotely triggered an avalanche from around 250 ft away while skiing down a ridgeline. The avalanche appears to have failed on pre-storm weak surfaces and gouged into old snow. An avalanche failed naturally on the north-facing steep gully walls sometime at the tail end of the storm.

column20: I remotely triggered one large avalanche and a couple of small avalanches. These avalanches occurred on steep NE-facing slopes around 10000ft and released on the mid-pack drought layer. column21: I remotely triggered one large avalanche and a couple of small avalanches. These avalanches occurred on steep NE-facing slopes around 10000ft and released on the mid-pack drought layer. Slab depths averaged 70 to 90 cm.   The storm slabs that were reported yesterday above Kebler Pass Road were no longer visible.

column20: There has been a wide variety of recent avalanche activity up to D3 in size. Many crowns appear sharp and have run in the past 24 hours.  There are many slides that were hard to see because they ran very early and those suspicious textures/faint lines are not coded due to uncertainty.  Most natural avalanche activity was west through north through southeast slopes near and above treeline.
column21: Given the distance size and date are a best guess but this appears to be one of the largest slides observed of the storm cycle.

column20: We targeted a couple of suspect slopes in Red Coon Bowl. NE aspects around 11600ft. With some targeted effort we were able to initiate a couple of collapses that resulted in remotely triggered avalanches.  Another natural avalanche is documented here from the other side of Red Coon Bowl.
column21: This avalanche looked fresh in one photo and old once we got a closer-up view. Hard to say the release date; it could be 2/14 similar to the Climax avalanches or early 2/15. More notable is how wide the avalanche propagated if it all released as one event. The crown elevations ranged from 11700ft down to 11200ft

column20: Flat light limited avalanche obs through the corridor.  I have documented avalanches where crowns were visible but many slides ran early in the storm cycle and are now obscured by later snowfall.  Each Climax Chute had some amount of debris in the runout but crowns were hard to see on most features.  Schuylkill Ridge showed lots of texture and lumps but debris in aprons was surprisingly hard to see with the exception of the D3 in Thanksgiving Bowl (previously documented) due to snapped trees in the debris.  Several avalanches ran early in the storm on southwest aspects and impacted the Slate River Road but the slopes were small.
column21: The failure date is a best guess.

column21: Slab avalanche that ran during the first half of the storm.  The failure date is a best guess.

column20: Remote sympathetic and ski cut 6 persistent slabs today on E to NE aspects below treeline breaking 2 feet deep.  A couple of large natural persistent slab avalanches likely ran during yesterday's increased winds along with many natural avalanches that ran during the storm.
column21: About 10"" of snow on debris.  Likely ran 2/14 or 2/15.

column20: Minimal wet loose activity today and one fresh wet slab on a SW aspect ATL that ran today above Copper Creek.  Coding numerous older persistent slabs that ran last week or during the storm.
column21: Unknown failure date. Older crown mostly filled in probably late in Cupid Crusher storm.

column20: Recent wet loose avalanche activity on the southern half of the compass was visible from both today and yesterday. These avalanches were small in size.  Additional old slab avalanches were also documented.
column21: Unknown failure date. Best guess

column20: I remotely triggered an avalanche from around 250 ft away while skiing down a ridgeline. The avalanche appears to have failed on pre-storm weak surfaces and gouged into old snow. The avalanche was on a northeast aspect near ridgeline. A member of the party also triggered a small avalanche on a southeast-facing gully wall. An avalanche failed naturally on the north-facing steep gully walls sometime at the tail end of the storm.
Avalanche from 02/14 storm cycle on ridgeline near peak 11049 visible from Park Creek Campground. The avalanche propagated across the entire ridge.
One large natural above treeline off North Twilight. Multiple small releases or one large? In steep cliff zone below treeline on summit of Coal Bank
Natural activity on northeast terrain at and above treeline.
Natural activity on northeast terrain at and above treeline.

column19: Steep slopes near the Cabins near Carbon.
column20: I triggered 3 D1 avalanches below treeline. All three avalanches failed at the new/older interface. On a more west slope the avalanches failed on a curst and on a more north facing slope that avalanche failed on weak faceted snow.
column21: Avalanches failed on a curst.

column20: Natural activity on northeast terrain at and above treeline.

column19: Steep slope near lower cabin coming from Putney gully.
column20: I triggered 3 D1 avalanches below treeline. All three avalanches failed at the new/older interface. On a more west slope the avalanches failed on a curst and on a more north facing slope that avalanche failed on weak faceted snow.

column21: This is the 3rd time this year this slope has avalanched. This may have been remotely triggered on February 14 or 15.

column20: Several small to large avalanches on east southeast and south-facing slopes up Carbonate Creek north of Marble.

This was one of the more active days on the Kebler banks that I've seen. 2 large avalanches hit the road 1 of those crossed the road the other left big enough pile to bury a person and close one lane of snowmobile traffic until the Irwin snowcat came through. Dozens of small avalanches ran in the storm snow including a couple hundred linear feet that dumped into the inside lane in the banks just down valley of the winter trailhead. It appeared most of the slides ran early in the day. Much of the evidence was filled in by the the afternoon.
column21: Buried one lane of Kebler Pass snowmobile route cleared quickly by local snowcat operator.

I drove along Highway 145 on Sunday morning and observed a minimal amount of natural activity then I toured in Waterfall Canyon and only found one recent natural Storm Slab avalanche below treeline and several slab avalanche that failed during the storm.

Two large to very large avalanches broke as wide as the avalanche paths are on the Carbonate avalanche path.. This path slid a few days ago but was notably smaller (https://avalanche.state.co.us/report/0cd894d9-4989-477e-8337-92ec09928531 ). The debris did not impact the quarry road but one of the runouts to the looker's right had debris make it nearly to the Crystal River.
column21: Debris ran stopped about 20 feet above the Crystal River

column20: Observed one recent avalanche on a wind-loaded north-facing slope and found some evidence of older avalanches on a few small steep slopes that seemingly had about 1 to 2 feet of snow covering the debris piles and crowns.
column21: Debris and crown mostly filled in with new snow likely went very early in the storm

column21: Debris piled up on the main bench a few hundred feet above the quarry road. The debris pile is estimated to be around 30 to 40 feet deep. Part of this path ran a few days prior.
Smaller storm slab avalanches due to loading out of couloirs.

column20: Evidence of a very large debris pile likely from the Valentines day cycle on the north side of Ant Peak. Debris made it across Yule Creek.

column19: Remote triggered about 100 feet away. The slab was several hundred feet across and mainly 45 to 75 cm's of storm slab but it did step down into deeper layers in one small area.

column20: Second-hand parking lot conversations suggest a party triggered an avalanche on a road cut while skinning and had been buried up to their knees. While small in size D1.5 the location was above a terrain trap. Additional natural avalanche activity observed on embankments.
column21: Triggered from below.

column20: The Thumb and Index in Five Fingers ran to the lower apron sometime before midday today.  D2.5 or more with a 3000ft or more track. Got a brief fuzzy view during a lull in the storm.

column21: Evidence of moving snow from early in the storm most likely small storm slabs D1 or D1.5s

column21: The failure date is a best guess.  I suspect these ran during high precip rates on Friday sometime.  It's hard to know if they are Storm Slabs or Persistent Slabs but I'd lean towards Storm Slabs.

column20: Small pockets here and there on ascent: early on road cut; east facing pitch below windy ridge (repeat offender) looked like it slid early in the cycle: just below windy ridge on the left a very small pocket on easterly tilt; the Skiers ahead of us triggered the  east facing stuff past windy ridge…. looked big; all of the East facing stuff on the west side of the bowl slid.  R1D1 remote trigger in little lady bowl; skiers right with easterly tilt.  On lap 2 skin cracking snow on edge or road cut where road and down slope meet.

column20: Three of the Climax Chutes had large avalanches.  The main chute in the middle had a very wide one across the top with a debris pile that came close to Mike's Mile and was a D2.5 or D3 the two to the lookers left had smaller crowns mid slope that didn't propagate as wide D2s.

column20: Flat light limited avalanche obs through the corridor.  I have documented avalanches where crowns were visible but many slides ran early in the storm cycle and are now obscured by later snowfall.  Each Climax Chute had some amount of debris in the runout but crowns were hard to see on most features.  Schuylkill Ridge showed lots of texture and lumps but debris in aprons was surprisingly hard to see with the exception of the D3 in Thanksgiving Bowl (previously documented) due to snapped trees in the debris.  Several avalanches ran early in the storm on southwest aspects and impacted the Slate River Road but the slopes were small.
column21: The failure date is a best guess.  A small crown is visible in the middle of the bowl but the volume of debris couldn't be from just that crown.  I suspect multiple events occurred over several days on this feature.

column20: I did not observe any avalanche activity this day just some minor pinwheels from rocks on south slopes. I did get a better look at natural avalanche activity that likely occure 2/14 and/or 2/15.

Around twenty arge to very large natural avalanches ran in the past few days (since we had good visibility on Sunday 2/16) from wind drifting.  Most of these appeared to be persistent slabs breaking on the January dryspell layer or deeper.  A few looked to be shallower wind slabs.  There's also lingering evidence of widespread natural activity during the big storm; I'm only documenting a handful of the more obvious or larger avalanches here.

There's also lingering evidence of widespread natural activity during the big storm; I'm only documenting a handful of the more obvious or larger avalanches here.

column20: Observed several Loose Wet avalanches from last week's warm-up and several older large avalanches that nearly made it from ridgetop to valley floor likely from the wind event in late January. Triggered a soft slab on a north-facing slope near treeline. This was the only open steep slope we got close to and triggered an avalanche immediately. The new slab still seems too thin soft and disconnected for larger remotely triggered avalanches but I am confident you could trigger an avalanche on most steep slopes facing north northeast or east above 11000 feet right now.

This avalanche occurred on a west-facing slope named East Bowl in upper Silver Fork in Big Cottonwood Canyon southeast of Salt Lake City UT. The crown face was between 10200' and 10300' and the toe of the debris was approximately 9500 feet in elevation. Slope angles in the starting zone ranged from 35 degrees to 40 degrees in steepness. The avalanche ran approximately 800 feet in elevation. Based upon the nature of the snowpack with its attendant persistent weak layers it is impossible to know exactly who triggered the avalanche.  On the day after the accident Utah Avalanche Center forecasters Dave Kelly and Drew Hardesty went toward the accident site to better understand the nature of the event. There was universal agreement however that conditions remained too dangerous to access the fracture line of the avalanche and therefore avalanche information is only conjecture based upon slope and snowpack history. Based upon zoomed-in photos from both the rescuers and the drone it is estimated that the soft slab avalanche was roughly 2’ deep. This potentially matches the layering of the faceted grains buried on February 1st and it could also match a weakness of graupel from the Friday February 7th storm. It is also conjectured that this slope had avalanched previously on December 29th leaving a layer of weak faceted snow on the bed surface. All three weak layers had been active prior to the accident.

This avalanche occurred on an east-facing slope in the Monte Cristo Range 30 miles northeast of Ogden Utah. The crown face of the avalanche was at an elevation of 8800 feet and the toe was at 8600 feet. This avalanche was 394 feet wide. The crown depth averaged 3 feet deep and was 5 feet deep at the maximum crown height.  This slab of wind-drifted snow failed on a layer of buried near-surface facets and broken precipitation particles and also involved the more deeply buried facets that formed near the ground in December of 2024. This was a hard wind slab with large chunks of debris remaining intact in the debris field.  Strong winds heavily drifted the upper portion of the slope creating a dense cohesive pencil-hard wind slab. The slope angle in the rocky area mid-slope was 43 degrees and the slope angle at the crown face averaged 31 degrees.  A notable terrain feature likely related to the extensive wind loading on this slope is the large flat meadow above and behind the slope. This meadow is a large fetch where wind can blow over land for quite a distance with no obstructions. The first available downwind terrain features are the two slopes in the leeward zone: Beer Hill and Whisky Hill. Even in a shallow snowpack season we can see depths of over 15 feet of snow (4 meters) on these slopes based on wind direction.

column20: A widespread wet cycle occurred in the vicinity of CR2 on Sunday caused by above-average temperatures. Small to large avalanches were observed on many aspects primarily near and below treeline. The Eureka/CR2 corridor often maintains a shallower snowpack sheltered low-elevation terrain and steep rocky geology; all things that often make this area one of the first to see natural instabilities due to warming and loading. This event is no exception and highlights the vast changes our snowpack is making despite limited snowfall in the past month.

After the first person in our group finished transitioning he began to ascend the south facing side of the gully. After a few steps a very loud whomph occurred and we witnessed nearly the entire visible part of the gully north and south facing collapse and crack sending a visible ripple through the snow. One small slide released on a steep enough section of the north facing side. The crown was probably 1-1.5 feet deep.

column20: We found a fresh natural avalanche on the lower flank of Hermosa Peak's north face.

On steep slopes near 40 degrees loose dry avalanches were often easy to trigger and were entraining most of the snowpack. We were traveling on benched terrain so sluffs couldn't run far and stayed small in size. Some slopes also had old wind effects that eliminated the potential for sluffs.

Underestimated the dry loose problem and the depth that the avalanches would gouge into the snowpack. Ended up having one member of our party caught and swept off their feet because of the dry loose problem.

The whole gauntlet inbetween Niagra and Eureka Mountain has slid (likely multiple times) this season. These avalanches will be recorded in a separate observation. On shallow slopes Dry Loose avanches were easy to trigger but small and slow moving.
Reporting parties could not clearly see the start zone of this avalanche so details on avalanche problem type size etc. are unknown or estimated at this time.

column20: Triggered a small wind slab by dropping a cornice chunk on the slope. East aspect at 11400ft. The slab was about 40ft wide and 8 to 10 inches thick. We also triggered several small loose dry avalanches up to 10500ft. Those sluffs were only reactive on old bed surfaces from the Thanksgiving or holiday cycles.

We did get a handful of collapses in low-angle terrain radiating up to 40 feet. Most occurred above 10000 feet in sheltered areas. The small amount of stiffness in the Holiday slab was collapsing on the December drought layer. I'm not convinced many features have this structure in steep terrain but the possibility of a slab in sheltered terrain lingers.
A 2-3 day old D1.5 in the thumb of five fingers. It went from the ridge proper to the upper apron. Broke cleanly at the ridge but didn't entrain much or pop anything else out on the way down

column20: Triggered a small wind slab by dropping a cornice chunk on the slope. East aspect at 11400ft. The slab was about 40ft wide and 8 to 10 inches thick. We also triggered several small loose dry avalanches up to 10500ft. Those sluffs were only reactive on old bed surfaces from the Thanksgiving or holiday cycles.

I observed a minimal amount of natural avalanche activity in this area: one recent Wind Slab avalanche several long running Loose Dry avalanches and one old Persistent Slab avalanche with an unknown trigger.

I observed a minimal amount of natural avalanche activity in this area: one recent Wind Slab avalanche several long running Loose Dry avalanches and one old Persistent Slab avalanche with an unknown trigger.

Intentionally triggered a handful of dry loose avalanches some were shallow and harmless involving the top 8"" of recent snow. On slopes that avalanched during the holiday cycle they would gouge into old snow up to 20"" deep and would have been more dangerous to get involved in especially in this long steep terrain full of trees rocks etc.
column21: On slopes that avalanched during the holiday cycle facet sluffs would gouge into old snow up to 20"" deep and would have been more dangerous to get involved in especially in this long steep terrain full of trees rocks etc.

column20: Tour around the Wolverine basin primarily on northerly aspects. Plenty of steep slopes along the road to skin up to Wolverine basin. Widespread cracking with sometimes sporadic collapsing. When walking on small rollovers/convex slopes there was easy propagating big cracks and collapsing. Some slopes would sluff the top storm slab of 6-10 inches. Occasionally gouging deeper into faceted snow beneath. Some slopes showed recent small slides. Skied open low-angle meadows to avoid steep slopes back out.
Small R1 / D1 avalanche near the east bowl of the anthracites. Broke to the ground.
column21: Small R1 / D1 avalanche near the east bowl of the anthracites. Broke to the ground. CBAC comments: Edited size to D1.5. It appears a ski track crossed the slab on the steep slope so the avalanche may not have been a remote trigger.

column20: I saw a handful of avalanches that released naturally in surface wind slabs. Crown lines were old and dates are best guess estimations.
I saw a handful of avalanches that released naturally in surface wind slabs. Crown lines were old and dates are best guess estimations.

column19: East-facing road cut near Corkscrew Pass. Estimated slopes angle just over 35 degrees.

column20: There were a few wet loosies that ran yesterday and numerous small wet loose avalanches ran today on southerly aspects typically from very steep rocky terrain. One triggered a shallow soft slab slab on Richmond.

column21: Loose dry avalanche which stepped down into a small slab avalanche.

column20: Avalanche #1 remotely triggered by skier  HS-R1-D2  11000' W/NW  Avalanche #2 sympathetically triggered by Avalanche #1  HS-R2-D2.5 12000' W/SW

column20: I saw a significant avalanche on a relatively small slope at 11100' facing East and in the trees.  This may have been a natural or I may have remotely triggered it from a long way away.  I checked out the crown.  The weak layer was about 10cm thick of 1mm fist hard facets. ECTP21 PST 25/100 end.  Higher up I noticed another small avalanche on a NE-facing slope closer to the ridge.  In the distance I could what looked like debris from an avalanche on Baldy (SW ~12300).  It was hard to get a sense of the size or character of that one.

column20: Ascending south facing ridge when we were approx 100’ from SSE rollover of the path to the east we heard a whumph and saw the slope crack and avalanche
column21: Preciously wind loaded area max slope angle 34 deg min 25. Ran where the path turned slightly more SE

column19: Slide occurred on a North East facing slope dropping into the small valley connecting the upper and lower Arapahoe lakes
column20: Skier in party triggered small avalanche descending slope near 30 degrees. The avalanche broke directly below the skier. The skier was the first to go down the other skier was waiting above. Skier remained on crust left behind as avalanche fell below and was able to back out safely. No one caught in it. Broke across the entire face sliding for 10-15 feet before stopping.
column21: Slope angle shading on GAIA GPS displayed an angle between 25-30 degrees.
New since we observed this slope on 1/10. Likely ran late 1/11 or early 1/12

column20: There were three distinct sides on NE-facing slopes. We were in the flatter sections below the slide at least 100ft below where the slide stopped. None of our tracks were in the slide path. The first slide was shallow 1-3ft deep where it broke but it broke about 800 ft wide and ran at most 200-300 ft. The second slide was in the narrow gulch where the small circular one broke first and then the larger one broke loose about 150ft wide with a depth of 2-8ft at the break and ran about 500ft. Again none of our tracks were in the slide path since we were riding in the ""safer"" areas nearby.

column19: HWY 550 just north of the first hairpin turn above Ironton
column20: SS-AS-R1D1-U BTL NW aspect at the top of Cemetary. Looks like it was skier-triggered from below as the group traversed west out of the trees and into the open on Cemetery run. Crown around 11400'. Coded in this ob. https://avalanche.state.co.us/report/11413fc6-57b3-4667-bd83-bdb48480459c SS-N-D1-U  BTL W aspect 10100' right across the creek from HWY 550 just north of the first hairpin turn above Ironton. Small avalanche but crown looked like it went down to 12/25 interface 2' estimated crown with 50' width.

column21: Most likely a natural small chance a cornice drop from someone on ridgeline.

column20: We saw two avalanches that ran below the ridgeline of Baker Mountain (one is pictured below). It is hard to know when the pictured avalanche ran. The smaller avalanche not pictured had a more distinct crown and flanks leading us to suspect it ran during or after the 1/11-12 storm.

HS-ASr-R1D2-O in Riley Boy (Imogene path). Seemed like it was triggered by second person on slope from about 400' below. Crown was ~1m thick bed surface seemed like the December wind event surface with facets above. Crown was 100m wide and debris flowed 200m vertical downhill. Crown connected rocks at top of path. Also observed a HS-N-R2D1.5-I small wind slab on the S aspect of US Basin peak below a small cornice. Another D1 soft slab BTL in the middle of one of the Brooklyn's gullies (very steep) which released mid-slope W-facing.

There were three distinct sides on NE-facing slopes. We were in the flatter sections below the slide at least 100ft below where the slide stopped. None of our tracks were in the slide path. The first slide was shallow 1-3ft deep where it broke but it broke about 800 ft wide and ran at most 200-300 ft. The second slide was in the narrow gulch where the small circular one broke first and then the larger one broke loose about 150ft wide with a depth of 2-8ft at the break and ran about 500ft. Again none of our tracks were in the slide path since we were riding in the ""safer"" areas nearby.

column21: A small bank slide above the road cut on FS Road 734.

column20: I saw many tiny debris piles throughout the Ruby Range at upper elevations. Most slides were covered by some amount of new snow. I suspect most were small sluffs or wind slabs. A couple D1.5's and a D2 on Gothic are coded here. Far in the distance outside the CBAC forecast area on a southwest slope of Mount Belleview (not the one at Schofield Pass) had a D2-looking slide from the wind event on 1/9 or 1/10 - hard to tell if it was a big Wind Slab or Persistent Slab as it was drifted over and debris was out of view.

column21: New since we observed this slope on 1/10. Likely ran late 1/11 or early 1/12. Couldn't see much of the slope could have been larger than a D1.5

Elk Mountain Ridgeline above Carbonate Creek
column20: Small avalanches on south-facing slopes above Carbonate Creek north of Marble. At least one was likely triggered by a cornice fall.

At least a handful of persistent slabs ran in the past 36 hours from wind drifting. Two looked very fresh: a D2.5 hard slab on the S to SE side of Teo and and a D2 on a SW facing slope near Twin Lakes. There were several other large avalanches near Hunter Hill Star Peak etc that also looked like they probably ran with the wind event though harder to say for sure.
column21: Could have failed 1/9 or early 1/10.

column20: Touring up Baxter Basin we experienced no signs of instability. However the wind/gusts were high and we saw the aftermath of four natural slides. While ascending the SW aspect of Cascade we noted a crown on Richmond's NE ridge. From Cascade's ridge a slide was visible across the gulch on Purple. After descending Cascade two small wind slab avalanches on SE/E aspects in Baxter Basin (~10800-10200) had occurred while we climbed the ridge/descended.

""Lots of recent and old activity up Castle Creek. D2.5 off of Sheep Peak. Peak to creek. ESE to SE aspect. Big enough that it ran down the Sheep 2 and Sheep Shoulder paths. Most debris in sheep 2 less in shoulder. Varioous older D1 and D2s in Hidden Valley. Fresh D1s on Candle Peak S-SE 1/10. Fresh D2 E aspect Candle Peak from 1/10. Recent D1 and D2 above Friends Hut SSW aspect with active wind-loading. It's an active moment in time out there.""

""Lots of recent and old activity up Castle Creek. D2.5 off of Sheep Peak. Peak to creek. ESE to SE aspect. Big enough that it ran down the Sheep 2 and Sheep Shoulder paths. Brief afternoon views of Schuylkill Ridge revealed a recent D1.5 persistent slab on a crossloaded east aspect that likely ran during the big wind event on 1/9 or 1/10.
West facing 11500 ASr judging from the tracks.  Probably within the past 24 hrs.

The main avalanche I was investigating is coded in a previous observation: https://avalanche.state.co.us/report/471d6925-c10f-4ff2-b13d-594c43d3d65e This avalanche broke wide across the entire ridgeline and even wrapped around terrain features to the north. There were a couple more avalanches I observed above the main one and in the bowl to the north.  I also triggered a small fresh Wind Slab avalanche that had reformed on the bed surface as I was mucking around. It would have been harmless if I was closer to it but it caught me by surprise.

After descending Cascade two small wind slab avalanches on SE/E aspects in Baxter Basin (~10800-10200) had occurred while we climbed the ridge/descended.

column20: Today Axtel 1st bowl center big hallway went. It failed about 200 feet below the headwall which I think the headwall flushed but lower down it went. Right as the slope mellows out about 30 degrees. My partner and I were leap frogging. They hit the headwall and skied down about 200 feet. Then I took it down to the gully and pulled off to the side. They went next and got taken out by a slide. They went for about a 100-foot ride and then were able to ride out of it. D1. They were fine but it was scary. I didn't get any pics.

column20: This was a hard slab avalanche small relative to the path but large enough to bury injure or kill a person. The avalanche broke into the old snow layers (HS-ASu-R2D2-O). The faceted snow layer formed during dry weather in December. Strong winds drifted snow onto the lee side of the subridge forming a strong and hard layer of snow (Pencil hard on the Hand Hardness Index). As the avalanche ran it stepped down to a deeper faceted snow layer in places. The avalanche was about 800 feet (250 m) wide and the crown face ran along a wind-drifted subridge of Red Mountain Number 3. The crown face was 3 to 4 feet (75 to 95 cm) high and almost 6 feet (175 cm) at the tallest point. The avalanche ran into a gully below the drifted ridge traveling 400 vertical feet.

This avalanche occurred just NE of the Broome Hut in First Creek. We believe another group at the hut remotely triggered the avalanche based on how close their skin track was to the avalanche. (The group’s tracks were found in conservative terrain.)
I saw one loose dry D1 avalanche on a northeast face in a steep gully. It released at a cliff band likely Monday afternoon.

As we traversed a 20-degree slope we remotely triggered an avalanche from 900 feet away crossing various terrain features and rocky outcrops. We had felt and heard several rumbling collapses along the way.

We remotely triggered one large persistent slab by stomping on a steep northeast facing slope from ridgeline (while holding onto a tree for safety). The crown was about 2 feet deep. We also conducted a crown profile of the large birthday bowl avalanche around New Year's. The slab is 60cm thick over very weak 2-3 mm chained facets: no signs of rounding just a garbage setup.

column20: On Saturday January 4 2025 at approximately 11:00 am four male skiers age 36-44 unintentionally triggered an avalanche on a north-facing sparsely treed slope above a steep-walled gully approximately one mile from the parking pullout for Breccia Mountain. The avalanche was remotely triggered from below as the party attempted to cross a gully beneath a wind-loaded ridge. The triggered weak layer was formed during a cold dry period early in the season. The weak layer was responsible for the region's numerous human and snowmobile-triggered avalanches the week preceding this accident. This avalanche propagated 350’ uphill to a wind-loaded 38-40 degree slope broken by cliff bands and across three distinct avalanche paths. The avalanche crown was 400’ across and ranged from one to four feet thick. The debris was a mixture of hard slab and softer surface snow which slid 625 feet (400 vertical feet) into a terrain trap (HS-AS(r)-R4-D2.5). The debris carried two members of the group resulting in one serious injury and one fatality.

A recent avalanche on a wind-loaded northeast-facing slope above treeline that likely occurred within the last two days. An older avalanche on a south-southeast-facing slope  near Sheep Mountain on a path that slid during the Thanksgiving avalanche cycle.

We then looked over to see the avalanche occurring South of us in steeper terrain. Due to time constraints and in consideration of our groups’s safety we were only able to view the avalanche from a distance and so can not verify the full relative size or vertical run. Another skier in the area went to investigate the avalanche and shared the video and several pictures with me.

column20: It was my first day of backcountry touring for the season due to some extended travel.  I have been reading the CAIC reports and had full awareness of the large number or remotely triggered avalanches that have been occuring.  I intentionally chose a different route up for this reason--typically I skin the north side of Illinois Gulch but today I skinned the meadow/glade area to the south of the drainage.  While skinning up through the meadow ( I was on a 5 degree slope at the time of the trigger) I felt a large collapse and moments later saw the avalanche just north of where I was skinning.  I didn't get my phone out fast enough to video the avalanche The first photo is from the point where I was skinning when I triggered it.  I skinned up 200' higher to get better photos of the slide. There were no ski tracks anywhere else in the Illinois drainage so i feel sure that no other parties were involved. Using CalTopo I measured 1100-1200 feet from my location to the crownline.  This incident was not a close call because of my distance from the avalanche and I was not in the run out zone.  It's yet another example of how touchy the snowpack is right now.

Probably ran New Year’s Eve or earlier. Maybe early New Year’s Day. Hard to tell if the dusting from New Year’s Eve was in the track or not. Could have been remotely triggered by skin track on ridge or natural. Not sure on D size of avalanche. Big east bowl on carbon. Crown was at least 150-200 yards long. Could not see extent of crown directly below skin track. Maybe 1.5-2 feet deep at crown. Looked like it entrained more snow further down avi track. Ran to flat area in bottom of bowl. To the ground most of the way down. Deposition field looked big. Not sure how deep. Persistent slab or wind slab below ridge line.

We remotely triggered all avalanches from the ridge above. We didn't stomp on the snowpack or try to get near the steep breakovers. Collapsing was continuous throughout the tour and often connected to the steep terrain below. Even in this short vertical terrain generally only 400 feet avalanches gain enough volume to hurt or bury a person.

Remotely trigger a small slope from ~20m at the Mayflower Gulch car park when stepping off the plow berm.

From the parking lot we were able to see a large crown above Heart Lake and just below the Continental Divide. The crown is estimated to be 6-7 feet at the largest point. Avalanche cleared out the slope to ground and most likely ran all the way down to Heart Lake and possibly over it. I estimate it to be an R4 D3 from the crown size. This was one of the larger avalanches I've seen in that area in 20 years of riding in this zone and is indicative of the avalanche problem for all of James Peak Wilderness right now- lots of wind loading on a thin weak base. Big steep slopes coming down from the Continental Divide are reaching their tipping point and are capable of producing large deadly avalanches. Unfortunately by the time we got to treeline there was no visibility to safely make further observations.

column20: All 5 avalanches were remotely triggered on an East Aspect near 11100 feet in the Black Lake Cliffs zone on Vail Pass. The first avalanche was triggered while skinning up a low angle slope connected to a very small steeper slope. The second avalanche a small slab above cliffs was triggered from above the cliffs while skinning. The final 3 and largest slides were triggered remotely when a skier in our party skied a pillow line and landed causing the a collapse that shot 100s of yards in either direction and triggered avalanches on adjacent steeper slopes.

column21: We dug a snow pit below the slide area (near bridge <TL) and got a PST END 40/100 but were not sure if it was the same failure plane since the PST failed on FC and the avalanche observed appeared to be a Storm Slab.

column20: Several avalanches in Bears Gulch occurred in the last 48 hours. They were likely remotely triggered but could have been naturals all within the same avalanche paths that slid on November 27 (see this observation:  https://avalanche.state.co.us/report/22dab7a5-4f6b-4c57-8b6c-79469fa9f8b7) highlighting how slopes that previously slid may be some of the more dangerous slopes now that we have a new slab. Triggered several avalanches on the north-facing slopes west of Hayes Peak above Hayes Creek some from hundreds of feet away below the slope and some only from a few feet away along the ridgeline.

Several avalanches in Bears Gulch occurred in the last 48 hours. They were likely remotely triggered but could have been naturals all within the same avalanche paths that slid on November 27 (see this observation:  https://avalanche.state.co.us/report/22dab7a5-4f6b-4c57-8b6c-79469fa9f8b7) highlighting how slopes that previously slid may be some of the more dangerous slopes now that we have a new slab. Triggered several avalanches on the north-facing slopes west of Hayes Peak above Hayes Creek some from hundreds of feet away below the slope and some only from a few feet away along the ridgeline.

A handful of large natural avalanches that appeared to fail with yesterday's snow/wind along with some older avalanches that ran during the weekend or Monday's wind event. These were mostly on wind drifted slopes the Cement Creek area saw fewer natural avalanches below treeline. Avalanche activity continues to fit the patterns that we have been observing with a slight uptick in southeast aspects above treeline where we suspect these recent avalanches broke from wind drifting onto the small-grained facets above the stout Christmas crust.

column21: Hard to see in flat light maybe a PSa or wind slab D1.5 or D2
Ran sometime between 12/28 to 12/30 probably during the wind event.

column19: The Railroad grade below the Trestle.

column20: This avalanche looked fresh on Monday.

""there was a flurry of avalanche activity on Highlands Ridge in the last two days. Multiple Crowns in South Highlands Bowl with debris making it to the lower apron above the creek. at least D2. Slightly older slide on Thumb and Index in Five Fingers that rolled just below the upper apron (picture) Smaller slides in K1 K2 and K3. D1 to D1.5s""

We saw multiple avalanches below the ridgelines of Sand Mountain and Meaden Peak on North through northeast through east aspects. They appeared to be natural mostly D1.5 to D2 on the destructive force scale and small relative to path. It was hard to gauge when they may have run but most appeared to have fairly intact edges so likely towards the tail end of the late December storm cycle and possibly during the 1/4- 1/6 storm.

column21: There were just a few inches of snow on the bed surface of the Quill. This avalanche started on the skiers right side of the bowl then propagated across the bowl lower in the terrain.

Wide propagation
Large natural avalanche to the skiers left of the Pencil. This avalanche had a few inches of snow on the bed surface.
This could either be a wind slab or a persistent slab couldn't tell if it broke on old snow or not.
Wide Propagation

column21: Small natural avalanches that occurred on steep NE convex rolls.

column19: Small test slope above a gully. Wind exposed.
column20: One natural and one human triggered slide on small steep wind-loaded southwest facing test slopes below treeline. In both cases the fresh drifted snow failed on a thin melt freeze crust. Wind slab depth varied from 10-60cm.

column19: Easterly ridge facing into Graham Gulch.
column20: An avalanche was triggered remotely on an Easterly(105º) aspect at 11815ft from approximately 70-80ft away. The slab communicated a collapse from a lower-angle Northeasterly slope over a ridge onto the steeper Easterly slope.

column21: The slides in Pic #2 occurred about 1pm as 2 skiers were skiing down the ridge to ski the lines looker left side of photo.   Skiers were about 20 feet from the crowns.
Repeat offender.

column20: Good vis today! Many natural avalanches up to D2 in size ran during the past few days. The natural cycle paused today but human triggering (almost all remote) continued. The terrain where we highlighted facet sluffs last week was most active in the last few days: west north and east aspects near and below treeline. Areas like Climax Chutes and Schuylkill Ridge saw extensive activity. Above treeline terrain was quieter but there were a handful of large avalanches. I only saw a few avalanches on southerly aspects; they were on SE aspects above treeline on Bichmond and Augusta.

Remote trigger skinning up mostly low angle ridgeline 11800 NW in Richmond Basin. D1.5 12” deep new/old interface. Slow moving but could knock you over. 30’ wide ran 80-100’. Plenty of collapses NTL none BTL

column21: Best guess is they ran during the Saturday night storm late 12/28 or early 12/29 because there is some fresh snow on the debris.

column19: Raspberry Ridge. Area locally known as DJ's Bowl.

column20: Extensive natural avalanche cycle over the past two days on shady aspects in the Slate corridor from Happy Chutes Climax Chutes Schuylkill Ridge and Purple Ridge. Most activity occurred near and below treeline. The alpine was quiet but given the stiff old surfaces up high before the storm it made some sense. There are dozens and dozens of other small D1s throughout the zone NOT coded here and many textured-looking slopes that likely ran early in the storm cycle but are hard to identify so not coded as well.
column21: This avalanche failed on 28th or early 29th. Coding reflects the large avalanche off the ridge.

column20: D2 E aspect BTL D2 NE aspect ATL D2+ N aspect NTL D1 N aspect BTL

column20: Saw two naturally triggered avalanches that slid overnight (12/28 into 12/29) due to the recent snow and high wind loading.  Both slides were in chutes on the wall near the Broome Hut.
column21: Both broke at the top of the path and to close to the ground. Estimated 4ft depth.

column21: likely triggered by Loose Dry avalanches above

Wang Chung had another widely propagating avalanche in it similar to what happened during the Thanksgiving cycle. We checked the bed surface of this avalanche on 12/30 and backdated the estimated avalanche activity from there. There were also two separate slabs lower in the terrain. It looked like the upper slab failed and then stepped down into an uglier-looking hard slab lower in the apron. These avalanches are coded separately.

column19: Schuylkill Peak - east bowl of sub peak
column20: Extensive natural avalanche cycle over the past two days on shady aspects in the Slate corridor from Happy Chutes Climax Chutes Schuylkill Ridge and Purple Ridge. Most activity occurred near and below treeline. The alpine was quiet but given the stiff old surfaces up high before the storm it made some sense. There are dozens and dozens of other small D1s throughout the zone NOT coded here and many textured-looking slopes that likely ran early in the storm cycle but are hard to identify so not coded as well.

Multiple SS-N-D2-O/G BTL from last storm cycle; 30-60cm crowns low in the paths depositing generally 1-2 meters of debris in the creek. x2 SS-ASc-D2-I 50cm x 10m x 100-200m from mid-path stopping on benches.
South of Uneva Peak.

column21: Coding the bottom right debris pile here. Looked a few days old but could have been drifted over by winds. Probably a persistent slab or wind slab.

column20: The avalanche occurred on an upper-elevation north-easterly facing slope west of Lamoille Lake. It was unintentionally triggered by a snowbiker. It was medium-sized relative to the path and produced enough force to bury injure or kill a person and break a few trees. The avalanche broke several feet deep and approximately 90 feet wide (SS-AMu-R3-D2). It occurred on an upper elevation rocky slope at 9965 feet which is exposed to the wind.

column19: This is a repeat offender rocky outcrop that faces northeast and usually harbors very weak snow.

A backcountry snowboarder triggered an avalanche while descending the east side of Marble Peak. The rider took one turn and heard his partners shout ""Slide"" so he kept his speed up and cut to the skier's left side of the slope out from underneath the avalanche. He then watched the avalanche travel several hundred feet until the slope angle decreased lower down in the path. His partners descended the bed surface of the avalanche and they all descended back to the trailhead safely.
Both recent and old avalanches on the west face of Hayden Peak.

Visibility was poor but we could see two natural avalanches immediately below Schuylkill Ridge. There was enough propagation in these wind-drifted avalanches to make them difficult to manage and it would best to avoid drifted terrain. We intentionally sought out small test slopes in sheltered terrain to get feedback on the developing Persistent Slab problem on northerly slopes and were able to find sensitive avalanche conditions. The entrainment of old snow created debris piles bigger than one might expect from foot-thick soft slabs.
column21: This natural avalanche likely ran early in the morning but possibly on 12/26. I made the best guess on size at D1.5 but it could be D2 with available old snow for entrainment.

column20: We saw numerous recent natural avalanches that were ""repeaters"" sliding in paths that released previously in the Thanksgiving avalanche cycle. We saw the crown of one large avalanche over a ridge on an east-facing slope off Hunter Hill that we think did not avalanche previously and so the crown was much deeper than other avalanches in the area.
A small cornice break triggered a Loose Dry gouging into older facets and running hundreds of feet to the low-angle meadows below the slope

column19: Little Italian Pass near Taylor Peak
column20: Easy to trigger long-running Loose Dry avalanches on any slope steeper than 35 degrees on the north side of Green Mountain. Observed a few older slab avalanches in Little Italian Basin and a more recent slab avalanche that likely failed during or just after the small storm on December 23 near Little Italian Pass.

column19: North slopes of Green Mountain above Ashcroft
column20: Easy to trigger long-running Loose Dry avalanches on any slope steeper than 35 degrees on the north side of Green Mountain. Observed a few older slab avalanches in Little Italian Basin and a more recent slab avalanche that likely failed during or just after the small storm on December 23 near Little Italian Pass.
Popped out a D1 windslab as we traversed into the main bowl from the west side ridge of mount Emmons. Crown was roughly 50ft across and ran on bed snow about 1-2ft down.
column21: CBAC Comments: The reporting party coded the avalanche as a wind slab on a south aspect. We revised the aspect based on their photos and description; the west side of the Red Lady Bowl is east facing and transitions to southeast in the middle of the bowl so the avalanche was on an east or southeast aspect. Because it likely broke on old weak layers that have been buried for two weeks we revised the problem to a persistent slab.

column20: I intentionally triggered a series of Loose Dry avalanches on a steep north-facing slope that had previously slid. These gained mass and speed as they entrained more snow moving downhill.
Remotely triggered an avalanche while putting in the skin track. Avalanche failed around 50 yard from me. Lots of cracking on the slope.
column21: Looked natural but old ski tracks in area.

column19: West side of Raspberry Ridge above Raspberry Creek
column20: Triggered a small slab avalanche on a northwest-facing slope below treeline. The avalanche was on a heavily wind-affected slope less than 200 feet below the ridgeline. The crown of the avalanche was about three to four inches thick and broke around 20 feet wide running about 250 vertical feet. This slope was more wind-pressed than wind-loaded with variable dense wind-hardened snow across the slope. This was the only pocket releasing an avalanche on a 37-degree slope. There was also what appears to be a skier-triggered slab from a day or two ago on a north-facing slope off Raspberry Peak into Raspberry Creek.
We saw three old slides that likely ran during or after the Thanksgiving Week storm and one slide that was more recent. They were are all directly beneath the ridgeline on the east side.
column21: This slide appeared to break on the December Drought layer but we could not confirm.

column19: Maid of Orleans in Peru Creek

column20: We intentionally triggered a small hard slab in crossloaded NE facing gulley. There were a couple of similar natural avalanches in this area that likely ran during the big wind events sometime last week also D1 in size.

column19: ""Little Bear Mountain"" above Sts. John just west of Montezuma.
column21: Maybe cornice fall triggered? Couldn't really tell...

column20: As I was traversing the low-angle saddle of Hahns Peak I remotely triggered a soft-slab avalanche that was small relative to path but large enough to injure a person. This appeared to break on the weak snow that formed during the early December drought (SS-ASr-R2-D1.5-O). I dug a profile above the crown and found that the snowpack was quite shallow (53cm) and consisted of 22cm of decomposing fragments above faceted grains and depth hoar. This occurred on a north-facing slope near the tree line of Hahns Peak.

column20: Observed a couple of large avalanches likely from November 27 and one widely propagating avalanche on the northeast-facing slopes below the ridgeline of Sellar Peak that likely occurred in the last week. I saw one small fresh slab avalanche on a southeast-facing slope. I also several cornice fall avalanches above Lost Lake. Interestingly these avalanches did not trigger any persistent slab avalanches. I also walked above steep east-facing terrain thinking I may remotely trigger an avalanche but no luck.

column19: Northwest slopes of Twining Peak above Roaring Fork River
column20: Several notable large avalanches from a couple of weeks ago during the November 16-17 natural avalanche cycle although many had been partially of mostly filled in with wind-drifted and hard to determine avalanche size. A couple of newer avalanches from the most recent snow and wind events mostly confined to cornice falls triggering small slabs and some natural Loose Dry avalanche activity.
column21: Both in gullies

column19: This may have been skier triggered or remote from the ridge? There were tracks seen close to the crown.

column20: The avalanche occurred on a sparsely treed northerly-facing slope north of Lookout Peak in the West Mountains. It was unintentionally triggered by a snowbiker. It was medium-sized relative to the path and produced enough force to bury injure or kill a person and break a few trees. The avalanche broke under a hard slab formed by the wind on a layer of faceted crystals above a crust (HS-AMu-R3-D2-O). The avalanche broke 2–3 feet deep and 240 feet wide. It ran 120 vertical feet into trees at the bottom of the slope. It occurred on a sparsely-treed slope at 7550 feet which is exposed to the wind. The runout transitioned abruptly from the steep slope to a bench that piled debris deeply relative to the size of the avalanche.

Much of this terrain naturally avalanched during the Thanksgiving cycle. Winds earlier in the week formed a thin slab immediately below a rib from cross loading. This feature avalanched during the Thanksgiving cycle. The snowpack below the slab was fist hard facets 2-3mm in size.

Observed three more recent avalanches all breaking just under the recent storm snow. One natural avalanche broke on a northeast-facing slope around 10500 feet on on old bed surface from avalanche activity during the Thanksgiving storm.  This is notable because it suggests that  areas that previously avalanched can no longer be considered go-to safe terrain in areas that picked more than about a foot of recent drifted snow. Another natural avalanche consisted of wind-drifted snow on an east-facing slope around 12000 feet.  Lastly a skier triggered a small slab on a steep east-facing roll over around 11800 feet.

Avalanche Summary Natural wind slab avalanche activity appeared to be isolated and small (D1-1.5). The largest avalanche observed was on the east face of Mt Owen. Previous wind slab activity was most commen on East to NE facing terrain. Small avalanches were visable a few other aspects too such as NW W and SE.

column21: Observed while driving by.

column20: A skier was caught and carried in a Loose Dry avalanche. The skier was unaware they triggered the avalanche further up the slope and as the avalanche gained mass and momentum it caught up to them and knocked them off their feet losing a ski in the process. The skier was able to self-arrest before being dragged into a stand of trees but lost a pole as well. Other members of the skiers group were able to locate their skis.

column19: This avalanche happened on an old mine dump.
column20: The avalanche we triggered failed on the 11/25 interface where newer snow sits above very weak facets on a steep shady north-facing slope. The avalanche happened on a steep mine dump at a convexity and where the slab was thinner. It was triggered from a hard turn across the top of the convexity and propagated around 30 feet wide.

Skier triggered a small slab while making a hard jump turn on an unsported south-facing slope at 12500ft. We continued to document the expansive natural avalanche events that preceded Thanksgiving. Most notably adding more large avalanches to southwest-facing slopes and adding another D3 for the east face of Mineral Peak.

column19: Mines 2 avalanche path on Colorado Mines Peak
column20: This was a hard slab avalanche unintentionally triggered by a backcountry skier. It was medium in size relative to the path and produced enough destructive force to bury injure or kill a person. It broke on faceted snow in the middle or bottom of the snowpack and ran to the ground in many places (HS-ASu-R3D2-G). It averaged two feet deep was over 600 feet wide and ran 800 vertical feet. The avalanche split in two partway down the path and the eastern section funneled through a narrow gully. The western portion of the avalanche swept Skier 1 downhill and ran through small sparse trees in the lower half of the avalanche track. Both sections of the avalanche converged at the bottom and piled debris over six feet deep in the ravine.

column20: Some of the slides in the photographs ran during or immediately after the Thanksgiving week storm. The two coded here likely ran in the last few days.

column20: Two people that were staying at Sisters Cabin returned to the hut after skiing up the north ridge of Bald Mt. They saw a slide with one track going into a crown and a little further west they could see what looked like boot kicks climbing back up on the climbers right flank. Slide ran out of sight into a gully. Later views indicated a fair amount of debris in the gully. Spread down 100 feet or so. Probably ran one of the last two days of November.

The area just to the north of Hocus Peak avalanched. This was a second hand report from skiers at the trailhead.

column20: We observed a wide avalanche on an east-facing near treeline slopes that ran during the storm. The crown looked deep but was already partially filled in. We intentionally triggered a small Persistent Slab avalanche on a steep short northeast-facing terrain feature. We observed a natural avalanche on a west-facing near treeline slope that occurred while we are out touring.
Avalanche from 11/26-11/27 natural cycle.
There was some natural avalanche activity in this area during the storm. Most avalanches were on the smaller side and the activity wasn't widespread.
These avalanches all likely ran during or shortly after the Thanksgiving Week storm.

Remotely triggered a large avalanche on a westerly facing slope at 10400ft. Interestingly this slope had old cracks through parts of the slope. The Slate River Drainage is a war zone of avalanche activity. We could spend a lifetime documenting avalanche activity out there. Widespread avalanche activity on northerly to easterly facing slopes. Many more natural avalanches on westerly facing slopes. Some natural avalanche activity on southerly facing terrain but they generally look like they fit in the storm slab category from afar. I'll add many photos to the ob and then start to document the most notable avalanches as time allows. Some of these avalanches were previously documented by Zach. Backster Basion continues on the war zone theme. Looks like some very wide propagating avalanches such as near Daisy Pass. Without being able to see the whole runout it's hard to classify everything.
column21: Remotely triggered a large avalanche on a westerly facing slope at 10400ft. Interestingly this slope had old cracks through parts of the slope.

column20: These avalanches all likely ran during or shortly after the Thanksgiving Week storm.
Prospect Mountain and Zion 1
Numerous in the forest on N NE and E in commonly skied tubes between 9600' - 10800'. Larger avalanches seen in paths below Star Peak
