Four large avalanches (the smaller side of D2) were reported. Two look fresh from when these photos were taken on Friday 11/29/24. Two look older and likely ran mid-storm.

More evidence of an impressive natural cycle was readily available during the tour. Of note one avalanche propagated wide near treeline into tall timber and released smaller sympathetic slides below treeline. The avalanche ran about 1000 ft the entire length of the path.  Many other avalanches observed in the vicinity that are recorded in separate observations.

column19: The meadows near the bottom of Money Shot
column20: This observation includes avalanches on Marble Peak and Mud Peak over to Di's Bowl
These slides likely ran during or immediately after the storm Thanksgiving week.

column21: Wide propagation across terrain features. Avalanche appears to be limited to new storm snow.

column20: Extensive avalanche activity some of it very large in size across all of the bowls that we viewed on Axtell. 2nd Bowl to Quill and Pencil to Wang Chung all ran wall to wall about 2 to 3 feet deep fairly late in the AR storm with about 8"" on their bedsurfaces. The debris out of Pencil/Wang Chung ran impressively far easily a D3. 4th Bowl ran earlier in the storm and the crown wasn't as distinct and the debris wasn't as extensive. 1st Bowl appeared to have many separate slides that released at various times throughout the storm. It was difficult to find any steep terrain unaffected by avalanche activity; the only intact snowpacks were small pieces of hangfire above the crowns on moderate slope angles.

Widespread natural cycle from Tuesday to Wednesday's storm on east north and west aspects. The only distinct avalanches that didn't fit this pattern was on windloaded S/SW aspects of Gothic Peak and Zacharys ATL. Extensive flush on most NE facing paths N/BTL and west to northwest was more active than usual probably because of the lighter winds and very shallow/weak existing snowpack there before the storm. Many large slides on Climax Chutes Schuylkill Ridge west side of Gothic and a few other alpine slopes of Emmons that I could see. Ruby Range remained obscured by clouds.

The debris out of Pencil/Wang Chung ran impressively far easily a D3. 4th Bowl ran earlier in the storm and the crown wasn't as distinct and the debris wasn't as extensive. 1st Bowl appeared to have many separate slides that released at various times throughout the storm. It was difficult to find any steep terrain unaffected by avalanche activity; the only intact snowpacks were small pieces of hangfire above the crowns on moderate slope angles.

Skier triggered a small slab while making a hard jump turn on an unsported south-facing slope at 12500ft. We continued to document the expansive natural avalanche events that preceded Thanksgiving. Most notably adding more large avalanches to southwest-facing slopes and adding another D3 for the east face of Mineral Peak.

column20: Skier triggered several shallow facet sluffs in steep terrain just large enough to push you around or knock you over. I'm adding a few smaller ones that we couldn't see from the road.

Several rumbling collapses as I toured below treeline. As I approached the electrical site I saw debris in the gully lookers right of the powerlines. Two tracks got about 10 feet from the rollover and remotely triggered an avalanche. The crown had a maximum height of 2 feet.

It was difficult to find any steep terrain unaffected by avalanche activity; the only intact snowpacks were small pieces of hangfire above the crowns on moderate slope angles.

Plenty of avalanches across the compass and at all elevations likely occurred between the 26th and 27th. Some notable ones were on the north side of Bald Mt and the bowl to the north and the west-facing slopes near Birthday Chute. Other smaller avalanches were observed on steep rollovers or the sides of steep gullies throughout the drainages.
An avalanche on a northeast-facing slope above Lift Line Rush and Nitro Chutes. A second avalanche skiers right of Lift Line in the trees.

Above 10500' we found it became very easy to trigger avalanches. As I walked along a flat bench with a steep slope below me I heard an loud whumph felt the snow underneath me collapse and then an avalanche released about 200 feet away on the steep northeasterly slope below me. The avalanche featured wide propagation along a convexity. The same collapse produce large cracks on adjacent slopes at least 200 feet away.  Other backcountry travelers in the area remotely-triggered two more avalanches from a flat ridge as they put in the skintrack. These avalanches released on steep north-facing slopes below treeline. The sensitivity of the slab is best described as ""touchy"" in this area.

Above 10500' we found it became very easy to trigger avalanches. As I walked along a flat bench with a steep slope below me I heard an loud whumph felt the snow underneath me collapse and then an avalanche released about 200 feet away on the steep northeasterly slope below me. The avalanche featured wide propagation along a convexity. The same collapse produce large cracks on adjacent slopes at least 200 feet away.  Other backcountry travelers in the area remotely-triggered two more avalanches from a flat ridge as they put in the skintrack. These avalanches released on steep north-facing slopes below treeline. The sensitivity of the slab is best described as ""touchy"" in this area.

Plenty of old crown lines had drifted back in likely running last night or very early this morning. I remotely triggered a large avalanche from around 200' away along the ridgeline. The maximum height of the crown was pushing seven feet. This is a heavily wind-loaded broad easterly-facing ridge. The slab was still soft and consisted mainly of new or recently drifted snow failing on a thin layer of facets at the ground.
Natural activity observed in the lower Champion hwy path West Lime hwy path Gobbler's Knob- Lime Creek and Quartzite Bowl- Snowdon shoulder.

column19: Snow Spur NW slide path area.
column20: The natural avalanches in the Snow Spur NW area had little to no snow on the ground prior to the storm. The start zone elevation is 10040'. The activity occurred a third of the way down the slope.  The pockets released in the White Lizard were near the bottom of the path and the most north-facing one had deeper coverage before the storm. Similar elevation band of 10100'.

More evidence of an impressive natural cycle was readily available during the tour. Of note one avalanche propagated wide near treeline into tall timber and released smaller sympathetic slides below treeline. The avalanche ran about 1000 ft the entire length of the path.  Many other avalanches observed in the vicinity that are recorded in separate observations.

column20: Upper Castle Creek did not miss out on this avalanche cycle. There are many small avalanches along road cuts and on steep slopes directly above Castle Creek below treeline on all aspects. The more significant avalanche activity occurred on larger slopes near and above treeline also on all aspects with the largest avalanches being on east and northeast-facing slopes above treeline. Basically every major avalanche path that threatens the road heading up Castle Creek had an avalanche with Durr 1 being the only one that nearly made it to the valley floor.

column20: Upper Castle Creek did not miss out on this avalanche cycle. There are many small avalanches along road cuts and on steep slopes directly above Castle Creek below treeline on all aspects. The more significant avalanche activity occurred on larger slopes near and above treeline also on all aspects with the largest avalanches being on east and northeast-facing slopes above treeline. Basically every major avalanche path that threatens the road heading up Castle Creek had an avalanche with Durr 1 being the only one that nearly made it to the valley floor.

It's hard to tell from the photo looking across the highway but with binoculars I could see crowns in Abe's and Old Man's. The crownline in Abe's looked like it extended the entire way across the ridge whereas in Old Man's it was concentrated just below the center cornice.

It's hard to tell from the photo looking across the highway but with binoculars I could see crowns in Abe's and Old Man's. The crownline in Abe's looked like it extended the entire way across the ridge whereas in Old Man's it was concentrated just below the center cornice.

Plenty of old crown lines had drifted back in likely running last night or very early this morning. I remotely triggered a large avalanche from around 200' away along the ridgeline. The maximum height of the crown was pushing seven feet. This is a heavily wind-loaded broad easterly-facing ridge. The slab was still soft and consisted mainly of new or recently drifted snow failing on a thin layer of facets at the ground.

I triggered multiple small avalanches on steep tailings piles with unsupported conex rollovers.
Every steep slope we traveled near would either spiderweb crack or avalanche on the old weak snow buried by this storm cycle. Visibility was too poor to see any of the surrounding terrain.

Many small avalanches on northerly-facing road cuts and tailing piles. Most were natural but some of these avalanches may have been triggered by the groomer or other riders. I did not observe any D2s.
I saw multiple natural avalanches that likely ran on November 26 2024.

Widespread natural cycle from Tuesday to Wednesday's storm on east north and west aspects. The only distinct avalanches that didn't fit this pattern was on windloaded S/SW aspects of Gothic Peak and Zacharys ATL. Extensive flush on most NE facing paths N/BTL and west to northwest was more active than usual probably because of the lighter winds and very shallow/weak existing snowpack there before the storm. Many large slides on Climax Chutes Schuylkill Ridge west side of Gothic and a few other alpine slopes of Emmons that I could see. Ruby Range remained obscured by clouds.

There was also a mix of avalanche activity that had occurred early in the storm around 11/26 and avalanche activity that occurred late in the storm on 11/27

Remotely triggered a large avalanche on a westerly facing slope at 10400ft. Interestingly this slope had old cracks through parts of the slope. The Slate River Drainage is a war zone of avalanche activity. We could spend a lifetime documenting avalanche activity out there. Widespread avalanche activity on northerly to easterly facing slopes. Many more natural avalanches on westerly facing slopes. Some natural avalanche activity on southerly facing terrain but they generally look like they fit in the storm slab category from afar. I'll add many photos to the ob and then start to document the most notable avalanches as time allows. Some of these avalanches were previously documented by Zach. Backster Basion continues on the war zone theme. Looks like some very wide propagating avalanches such as near Daisy Pass. Without being able to see the whole runout it's hard to classify everything.

I was last skier to descend the NE slope. First two turns were soft third turn entered into wind crust and triggered a small slide. I fell back into the slope but was not carried. Slide was approximately 10 feet wide 3 inches deep and slid on the interface of the wind hardened snow and the facets. Slide ran approximately 50 feet.
Visible crown looker's right of ""Cornice"" just below ridgeline. It is most likely a wind slab avalanche from a natural trigger.

On the descent I skied across the top of a small convexity where an open slope meets some dense trees. I triggered a small wind slab that broke at the convexity. The crown was between 4-6 inches deep around 20 feet wide and the soft wind slab broke into powder in the debris. This was on a north-facing slope at 11000'.

South Diamond Peak.
I triggered a very small avalanche on a small test slope by stomping my ski onto the hard snow. Cracks shot out from my ski and remotely triggered a small 20 ft vertical slope.
Hard slab debris seen from a northwest-facing steep rocky cross-loaded terrain feature. Likely failed naturally during the wind event that occurred November 15/16th.

column21: Looked to be triggered by wind-loading.

column20: This is a small wind slab avalanche sent to me via social media (thanks for sharing!). This avalanche failed around 12600' lower down on an above treeline slope. The crown appears to be one to two feet thick and broke along several shallowly-buried rock outcrops.
One Wind Slab likely from one or two days ago further up Yule Creek in steep cliffy terrain.
Small windslab over exposed terrain guessing it ran during the wind event on Friday.

A recent large natural avalanche was observed. This avalanche may have been triggered by cornice fall from recent drifting. Although the avalanche was relatively narrow the debris pile was deep enough to bury a person.

column20: I saw one natural avalanche on Purple Ridge that ran yesterday at 11600 feet.  Near Elko Park around 10500 feet in a cold-sink steep creek wall I could push tiny amounts of faceted surface snow as a loose sluff.
Natural near Chicago Ridge

Group of three traversed out to NW facing Halloween Bowl. Strong downslope winds predominated on both the northern facing slopes along the traverse around to Halloween Bowl and within the bowl. Not sure if these winds were actually southeasterly or just strong downslope winds. Much snow was being transported mostly downslope but strong gusts upslope as well. Midway through the bowl regrouped at safe spot. No cracking whumpfing or other signs of instability presented. Snow surface was generally variable wind buff with a thin wind crust on the north and east aspects of the bowl. But we had found no significant consolidation while poking around the snowpack. Skier 1 poked out into the second pitch a wide gully with the plan of dropping across the west-facing terrain to enter the gut of the gully. Almost immediately and with very little pressure the skier triggered a windslab that ran ~200' to ~300' vertical feet. The skier had entered at about 29/30 degrees but the slope rolled over within 4-5 feet downhill into 33-35 degrees sustained for about 300 vertical feet. The slab ran most of this length but the pitch lessened and the mass came to a stop. It did not propogate all the way across the gully and did not entrain the more easterly facing side of the gully. Thankfully Skier 1 remained safely at the crown. Though a portion of slab cracked and broke a few feet above Skier 1 it was not steep enough to slide with the rest of the slab. Slab was about 25-30 cm. The bed surface below the crown was surprising we hadn't found anything that would suggest the presence of this layer. We failed to reevaluate the subtle change in aspect and given the significant wind loading we should have done so.
Observed one slab avalanche on a very wind-loaded slope from a distance.
The avalanche was viewed from a distance so it is hard to know what it broke on. It looks like the avalanche broke widely around several terrain features and stepped into older snow layers.
A small natural Wind Slab avalanche off an east-facing slope on an east-facing slope

One avalanche I saw was in very steep easterly terrain and appeared to be triggered by a skier. The other was older probably from 11/8 or 9 and was from steep rocky terrain. The avalanche is from an area that usually slides multiple times a year.

column19: Small natural avalanche on the west side of Red Mountain Pass.
column20: Small Wind Slab avalanche triggered by snow loose avalanche activity.

column19: Steep northwest slopes northwest and above Mineral Point
column20: Observed a few Loose Wet avalanches on steep south-facing terrain throughout the afternoon and one possibly Wind Slab avalanche on a northwest-facing slope (hard to tell if it was a slab from that far away but it looked like it had a small crown.)
column21: Not positive it was a slab but appears to be from a distance

column20: Released a small wind slab on an open northeast slope adjacent to ridgeline. Slope is about 38 degrees and is a typical loading area during prevailing southwest winds. Wind slab was about 2-3 inches deep slow moving and traveled about 600 feet down mountain without gouging any deeper than surface snow.

Looking down the Ruby Range there were many small avalanche debris piles below steep terrain. I couldn't see any notable crowns as they had either already been blown over or the avalanche debris were from sluffs. We got up close to one wind slab avalanche on Purple Ridge that had produced a decent-sized debris pile and the crown on that avalanche had also already been blown back over. All natural avalanche activity looked to have occurred on Tuesday (11/12) during the first 3/4th of the storm.
A couple of Loose Wet avalanches were observed on southerly-facing slopes in the afternoon.
column21: The avalanche started at a southeast-facing cliff band and traveled several hundred vertical feet.

column19: Kellogg avalanche paths above Castle Creek
column20: A couple of Loose Wet avalanches were observed on southerly-facing slopes in the afternoon.

column21: Maybe triggered by rockfall
Could not clearly see a crown line but there was debris in the track to mid-path.

column20: Small Avalanche on a Wind Loaded East aspect off of Purple Ridge.

A fresh wet avalanche that ran today. Several soft slabs and sluffs that ran on the northern half of the compass between Tuesday and Wednesday AM. Some of them gained notable volume as they ran through large terrain but everything we saw remained small in size D1 to D1.5

column20: Several small Loose Dry avalanches on slopes steeper than 40 degrees likely triggered by snow falling off trees.

column20: Natural release on a N/NE aspect NTL ~ 11600ft in a steep complex gully system. Thinking it failed at the old interface in the early hours of 11/6 during peak precip.
column21: the slide seemed to ride on the old interface with no step-down behavior
